captions.text: I love their giant ears.

Yeah.
- They're like leaves.
It's for that sonar.
It's like having two satellite dishes on your head.
You get all the good channels that way.
So many bats.
So many bats.
I'm gonna move some of these boxes.

Monotremes.
- Monotremes!
We don't have very many,
but we do have this guy.
He's extra special. Do you know what that is?

Is it an echidna of some kind?
-Yeees, it is.
This person just left the tissue in there,
so you kind of can get a rough sense, you know,
profile view of his body, but they have these great claws,
these digging claws, with these huge nails.
And this is the radius and the ulna and they are, you know, almost fused together,
they're very thick, very stout.
You can tell they're a primitive mammal
because they have these extra pelvic bones
that, like, point forward and I'm not entirely sure what they do.
But possums also have them.
This is their crazy little skull.
They don't have any teeth,
they have really long tongues

Oh god.
- What?

Papyrus...
- Nooo.
I didn't make it!
This whole cabinet is full of all kinds of creatures of curiosity.
We have possums, and they're really kinda gross looking, I don't really like 'em.
I can't have a bias.
This is a little guy but you can get... the same thing.
They have tiny, tiny brain cases.
It's like they have these itty bitty brains.
And this desn't grow. Their sagittal crest grows as they get older,
but the brain case stays this small.
They're just like the stupidest animal.
I think they have 48 or 50 teeth

That's a lot of little teeth.
- Lot of teeth.
Lot of like nasty; so they're basically just like teeth, teeth with bodies.
Not a lot of thinking power going on.

Guess what?
- You're gonna make me guess?
Guess what?
I don't, I don't know. That's very big.
I cannot say.

It's a kangaroo.
- Oh!

Yeah.
- I would not have got there ever.
Yep, they're pretty cool.
But they have these really interesting front shovel-like teeth,
- Yeah.
that kinda just point straight forward
They have... they're part of this, um, this order Diprotodontia,
which is "two forward facing teeth."
Did you know that there are prehistoric elephants that have those?

Really?
- Yeah.
Oh yeah, the big shovel teeth,
the big scoopy things.
Yeah, I can't remember what they're called, but they are nuts
and terrifying.
They used them for, like, digging stuff up,

but it looks like they used it for decapitating humans.
- Like in mud.
Which didn't exist then, so.

We were safe.
- Yaaay!
I've got a wallaby skin in here, too. That's pretty neat. Kinda flat.
Looks like a bunny with a big tail.
Yeah, that's an interesting...
Feels like a bunny, too.

Everybody likes the little owls.
- Awww, owls!
They're pretty cute.
Owls on sticks.
We do have snowy owls and every time we open it, kids are like: Hedwig!
Except not like in the last 2 years 'cause kids don't read Harry Potter these days

Ugh!
- What's wrong with them?

No.
- I said: "Get out of my museum."

comments.text:
(0:13) I had to look it up, so here it is (from Wikipedia): "Monotremes are 
mammals that lay eggs."  
"Echidnas, sometimes known as spiny anteaters... Although their diet 
consists largely of ants and termites, they are no more closely related to 
the true anteaters of the Americas than to any other placental mammal. They 
live in Australia and New Guinea."﻿

comments.text:
Oh my...I just found your channel from SciShow and I'm already in love with 
it. Seeing all this makes me even more excited to start my studies in 
biology next week. But I don't think my university in Montreal has such a 
big collection... I would love to explore a place like that, so 
inteeerrresting, I would be there for HOURS looking in every corner. Have a 
good dayyy & AGREEING on the Harry Potter part by the way :) (english being 
my 2nd language sorry for any mistake/grammatical error)

comments.text:
The youngest record of Amebelodon is from a 5 million year old site in 
North Africa. Lots of hominids were around at that time: Sahelanthropus 
tchadensis dating from 7 million years ago Orrorin tugenensis dating from 
5.7 million years ago Ardipithecus kadabba dating to 5.6 million years ago 
Australopithecines arose around 4 million years ago

comments.text:
I am always a little upset when someone say an animal was not very smart 
because it has a small brain. Creatures only need to do 2 things, eat and 
reproduce. Many with small brains have done that for thousands and maybe 
millions of years. Instincts = survival. And all animals are much smarter 
than we give them credit for. And they were smart enough to not ruin the 
earth. A little brain might can do more than we think.
comments.author: spittenkittens
